Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 6ece21fb23730c3af1b1e90bd246469c9d35fd55
you could add a brief description of the command and add the spec details(section, table etc) to make it easy for reviews.

+1

Can you also add a negative case example?
could you please add unit test for this?
Added unit test for the same
declare this variable only if the getNumericEffecterData() returns a success?
you could point to the spec to specify the table of the command format here.
Added the comment for explaining the magic number
nit: this is not quite readable. Change if you feel necessary.
+1, as we are adding it twice , its better to add an inline comment about what each addition is about.
Can we have the check in uniformity, starting from uint8, uint16, uint32 and uint64?
if pdrRecord is NULL how does this behave? do we need a check and return error?
line516 handles NULL pdrRecord check and returning error is taken care at line529

For my understanding: why did you choose to use nested try-catch blocks? 
can this be moved to as a different function rather than nesting the try block?
Added the code in single try catch block
This does not go really well with rest of the functions in this file. I believe libpldmresponder/pdr_utils is probably the right place for this & not common/utils. As this is PDR(effecter) related.

seems like these variables are initialised to defaults consuming memory. But they are just being used for calculating the size ?

Why can't we use scoped type alias - https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/type_alias ? and eliminate the memory allocation ?

something like :

```
using completionCode = uint8_t;
using effecterOpState = uint8_t;

responsePayloadlength = sizeof(completionCode) + sizeof(effecterOpState)
```
please have this consistent across the business logic and the test code.
check also if the effecterValue returned is expected one.
This is the bad path usecase where EffecterID was not found inside the PDR repository. So will not get the effecter value.
